story:
Creating a communal performance space

It's incredible to think Gaza has been under blockade for almost a decade. We can't go there; they can't come here. So we're creating a place where people can meet - a communal, virtual performance space. 

Using a mix of live-streaming and recorded video, artists occupy each other’s homes, streets and other social spaces to share their everyday lives. At times they even dissolve into each other or become ghostly protagonists in the drama.

At the beginning of the year, the London International Festival of Theatre gave Station House Opera a two-week residency to work with a group of artists in London and Gaza, followed by a public sharing on 17 January at Watermans Art Centre in London and Al Meshal Theatre in Gaza City.

Having established a brilliant team and tested the technology, now we're developing the work into a full production for 2017/18 - with a month-long workshop and rehearsal period from 17 October to 13 November this autumn.

During the workshop twenty artists from a variety of disciplines - including theatre, film, visual arts and photography - will focus on developing their stories and interactions into final material for the full production in Gaza and London.

At Home in Gaza and London is all about artistic collaboration. It brings together performers and audiences in utterly different situations to share a common enterprise. Which is where you come in.

What we need 

We're thrilled to be working with such a vibrant community of artists on this ground-breaking project. But we need your help to make it happen.

We need to raise funds now, or the four-week workshop in October won't go ahead.

When you contribute you'll not only give artists in Gaza the chance to work with their contemporaries abroad, you'll also make sure they get the international attention they deserve.

Every donation we receive will go directly to developing the At Home in Gaza and London project into a full production.

Your contribution will go towards covering the cost of renting space for the workshops and public sharings in London and Gaza, ensuring we've got the equipment we need, and paying all the artists.

There are some excellent perks too, from free tickets and a sumptuous Palestinian meal, to meeting the artists and a virtual tour of Gaza.

You can also help by spreading the word and making some noise about our crowd funding campaign.

And we'd love you to join us for our public sharings!

What others have to say

Actress Miriam Margolyes: “I totally support this exciting project. My only visit to Gaza was 25 years ago. I shall never forget it and when I see the video of the Station House Opera performance I realise how vital the contribution of the Arts is, in bringing people together and a sense of hope back to a place blighted by Israeli intransigence. May it flourish and prosper; I welcome such innovation, using live performance & digital invention to transform our world.”

Producer Brian Eno: "After the most recent destruction in Gaza, in 2014, the nations of the world got together and decided to DO SOMETHING. Between them they pledged €5billion to rebuild Gaza. And then they all got on planes and went home - and, mostly, forgot to send the money. As a result, Gaza is still a massive bomb site, with families living among piles of broken concrete, damaged hospitals functioning as best they can, and no prospect of anything like a normal existence for the 2 million people trapped there. We can’t let this continue…and, if we start understanding what is really happening there, through creative projects like At Home in Gaza and London, we won’t let it continue."

Filmmaker Leila Sansour: "This is a truly inspiring project which celebrates the power of art to break barriers. Not unlike the tunnels of Gaza, this work is a virtual highway that provides a link to a creative community in a city that has been shut away from the world. What an ingenius way for artists in Gaza to work with their contemporaries abroad and to have access to international audiences.”

Author Hanan Al Shaykh: "When occupation and violence tarnishes humanity and kills. Art cleanses and brings back justice and life."

The team

Co-director Julian Maynard Smith is the artistic director of Station House Opera with whom he pioneered the use of real-time video streaming to link performance spaces in theatre productions in the early 2000s. From 2009-14 he held a fellowship at the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama, developing the technology and dramaturgy of Telematic Theatre during which he produced Nowhere (2010-13), The Doors (2014) and The Apartment (2015). In 2014, Station House Opera produced Dissolved, linking the Sophiensaele theatre in Berlin with Beaconsfield Arts in London.

Co-director Taghrid Choucair-Vizoso is a Lebanese-Spanish performer and theatre-maker with a practice in contemporary work in or about the Middle East - particularly Lebanon and Palestine. She creates and performs work within the context of cultural resistance and facilitates workshops with refugees. She has been participating in Station House Opera events since meeting Julian Maynard Smith in 2010.

Gaza co-ordinator Najlaa Ataallh is a novelist and project coordinator who currently works with UNRWA’s Gender Initiative in Gaza. She has been a mentor in a big sister programme led by Gaza Sky Geeks, a Coordinator at the Tamer Institute for Community Education and an animator in the Stories Club at Arabic Nasr Club and Al-Zaytoun Club in cooperation with the Tamer Institute

Performers in Gaza: Aya Abdelrahman, Abeer Ahmed, Isa el Alem, Ahmed Hamza, Ali Hassany, Mahmoud Madi, Mariam Nasser, Ismael Rozzi, Hamza Saftawy, Walid Tafesh

Performers in London: Zoe Aiano, Tara Fatehi, Lia Ikkos, Yoko Ishiguro, Jenny Matthews, MH Sarkis, Owl Young

Technical directors in Gaza and London: Hani Mortaja and Paul Stroud

At Home in Gaza and London is a Station House performance project produced by Pressure Cooker Arts and Artsadmin.

story:
It's been 4 years since 2012's "Who's Gonna Teach You How To Live?" ... 

In that time I've done a lot of living/learning/writing/recording/touring/working day jobs/ I read a few books/etc AND made a lot of fans. People have been asking me, "So Jordan, when's the next album?" or they'll walk up to the merch table and say something like "You were really good! But is your music on vinyl? I only buy vinyl..." 

Well, I have 12 new songs professionally recorded in a studio here in Nashville with top session musicians and the works! If you want Jordan Hull on vinyl and the new full-length album unleashed on the world, it's all ready to go! BUT I NEED YOUR HELP!! 

This campaign is a pre-order. The hope is to have Vinyl and CDs pressed and shipped by Thanksgiving, so on Christmas day (or Hanukkah) instead of playing Bing Crosby folks will be listening to the new installment of the Jordan Hull mythos!

(All physical orders include a signed glossy photograph so you can tell people you know me! Plus there are other exciting perks so don't wait!!!) 

The vinyl art is beautifully designed by young Third Man Records employee, Jessica Yohn (who I may get fired for dropping her name.) It includes a fold-out lyric poster and the vinyl itself will be pressed on the highest grade vinyl possible with full attention to sound quality! 

I poured my sweat and blood and sanity into this album. It's my life's work. Please help me finally release this thing! I'm no longer a label stooge and I don't intend to lose the directness of being indie. I can't do this without your help... 

All the love, 

Jordan Hull

story:
Short Summary

Greetings from the Adivasi Arts Trust!

Thank you for your support for the short film   short film 'How We Got Fire'.  The story   is an adaptation from the oral narrative traditions of the Andamanese people, and it will be included in a  series of short films  currently in development.

I am Tara Douglas,  Secretary of the Trust and a Trustee of the Trust for Tribal Art Culture and Knowledge.    I completed a Professional Doctorate in Digital Media in 2015 at Bournemouth University  for my research titled 'Tales of the Tribes: Animation as a Tool for Indigenous Representation'.   It brought extensive practical experience  of  animation film-making  and  coordinating projects with indigenous, tribal and Adivasi young people to translate their stories for the medium of animated film,  and in 2017 the Adivasi Arts Trust received the ENGO award for promotion of culture.  My research  is based in India, and we  have now produced two series of animated films and a full length documentary film for national broadcast in India.  

The  research  highlights the dilemmas that are faced by the diverse tribal communities of India:  these people are socially and economically marginalized and their art, culture  and stories remain widely unknown and unrecognised by society.  The most extreme case would be that of the peoples of the Andaman Islands: there are very  few survivors, and their fragile languages and cultures  are immanently threatened.      Prior to this pandemic and lockdown, I had initiated  processes to contact local people for their involvement in the project:  the region is a sensitive area,  these communities are classified as Particularly Vulnerable Tribal Groups and  special permission for research is required from the Tribal Welfare Department. 

I plan to visit Port Blair and to coordinate with the  Department and the Anthropological Survey of India to organise a series of storytelling workshops so that we can invite participation from local people in the project.  In this setting, the objective is also to  arrange for them to create some artwork and animated sequences for the film. I  also plan for  young digital media professionals and students of animation in India to assist  the production of the  short film,  and  hope to translate and dub it into the local Andamanese language, as well as into English and Hindi.

This will be the first initiative to study the narrative traditions of the region using the medium of animated film.  The media project aims to broaden awareness, interest and understanding of the  indigenous values by  highlighting the  intrinsic reciprocity in relationships of  interdependence with the natural and supernatural worlds  upheld by these small communities.   It is important, timely and appropriate  to celebrates the knowledge, culture and artistic practices of these unrepresented peoples,  and to become aware of the unprecidented impact on traditional  ways of life that has taken place  in tandem with the accelerated destruction of the natural environment.    It is hoped that the project will also encourage the few  remaining Andamanese people by the appreciation that is shown towards their culture,  and   the empowerment through their participation.

The film-making activity must be carried forward with great sensitivity and as the project coordinator, I will be seeking sustained  contact with members of the community throughout the process.  The  film of 8 minutes duration will explore the use of mixed media techniques:  handmade artwork that can  be created with local inputs to enhance a visual aethetic would be appropriate to the content of the narrative,  and digital technology  embeds a high standard of production and post-production so that the film can be viewed by audiences locally, nationally and internationally at festivals and institutions of culture and education.  

The avenues that have been explored to support  this work are currently unavailable.  Therefore your contributions are vital to sustaining the project to its completion.  This campaign is a continuation of the work. We are very grateful for your support and hope that you will continue to help us to bring the project to completion.  

What We Need & What You Get

Approximately 10,000 images must be designed and recorded for this short film, demanding  sustained commitment from the team.  It is anticipated that the production will one year to complete:  the challenges of engaging with members of the community to make this work as a  participatory media project are immense. 

This  estimated financial requirement  for this project is  ₤5000 Stirling (UK).  The earlier campaign achieved some of the target funding, which has taken the project forward, as you will see in the video for this campaign.    This campaign is an update on the project, and the funding requested is for:

1) Field research to coordinate a series of workshops and engage local participants including domestic travel and fees to interpreters and translators.  

2) Technical costs for equipment (hard drives, back up, internet, audio recording, editing, mastering).

3) Stipends for the artists engagement in the work.

4) Communication costs for maintaining contact with academic institutions, stakeholders and consultants.

5) Dissemination  to stakeholders, supporters and viewers.

This is a non-commercial production that  represents good value for money.  As the project is based in India,  the costs are required for domestic travel, which is key to achieving the goal of collaboration with local people.  My prior experience is the foundation to  adjust  to diverse circumstances, the capacity for improvisation and the  measured use of our available resources.   If, for any reason the film cannot be completed, the funds raised will contribute to the parent project, The Stories of Our Ancestors (towards workshops for tribal participants, planned at the North Eastern Hill University in Shillong, Meghalaya)

The Impact

This  media project is an earnest attempt at  contributing to the  dialogue about the historical and contemporary culture of the  Andamanese peoples:  to date,  little is known about them; their traditional way of life is rapidly vanishing and, suspended as they are  between the arguments for isolation and assimilation, their own indigenous cultural traditions and languages remain mysterious, undervalued and unrepresented.  By your support, you will become  part of a story that promotes the values of sustainable living and protection of nature which are at the foundation of these cultures. Your contribution will help to  document and share indigenous knowledge,  and you will be enchanted by storytelling of a completely original style.

Our previous media projects have reached audiences   across India, the UK and further afield, through  screening tours, workshops, seminars, conferences, at cultural events and festivals, and my existing links with institutions, government and non-goverment organisations will be key for  achieving the delivery of this project and its dissemination.  The short film, 'How We Got Fire' will be included in the 'Stories of Our Ancestors' project  with associates in North East India, which will further promote its proliferation as cultural and educational material.  

 

Risks & Challenges

My  commitment and prior experience in this field of research is the  pathway to address the risks and challenges to the project.  It is expected that visitors will once again be permitted to travel to the Andaman Islands when the temporary  closure has been lifted to the region. Permission has been applied for  research with the Andamanese and Ongee tribal groups residing in restricted areas.  In any case, it would be feasible to organise  workshops  in Port Blair with  local government assistance.

I maintain strong links with indigenous communities in North East India and it is viable to base the production at the North-Eastern Hill University (NEHU) in Shillong, where I am associated as a Post-Doctoral Fellow in the Department of Anthropology, in the event that I am  unable to carry out this work at the field research site.   Workshops for tribal participants and students can be organised at NEHU to develop the films and students of media and animation would  then be invited to lead the media production.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about this unique cultural project by sharing this Indigogo campaign with your friends.

story:
Cyborg Shamanism: An alternative to the traditional Hero’s Journey.

Instead of focusing on a solo adventurer we all travel together. Join me and become a part of our immersive storytelling future.

 

​“You never change things by fighting the existing reality.

To change something, build a new model that makes the existing model obsolete.”

― Buckminster Fuller


 

The old ‘normal’ is well and truly broken.

The COVID-19 pandemic has subverted the status quo, we can’t go back to what was. 

Do we really want to anyhow?

What we once knew to be ‘normal’ no longer exists. As devastating as the impact of COVID-19 has been we have also been presented with an opportunity. An opportunity to leave old beliefs, rituals, behaviours and narratives behind. To remember to breathe and to grow alone and together. To remind ourselves of what being in flow feels like and to ground ourselves in these new rituals and stories of who we really are when we remove many of the distractions.

I was one of the many thousands in the UK who had to shield, the harshest form of lockdown because I am immunocompromised. I started the year with speaker gigs booked through until August 2020, after 10 years on the Keynote speaking circuit this was a first. I had finally broken through. All of the sacrifices had been worth it. And then, the coronavirus struck. Within 2 weeks I had lost all of my work and potential earnings for the year and possible longer because I had to shield.

 Instead of seeing the lockdown as a quarantine I chose to see it as a period of metamorphosis, of transformation. A time to create some new isms.

Whilst in my cocoon I noticed three things about what was happening in the world outside:

If we break down human made boundaries and come together then we are capable of much more than we could have imagined

Empathy, compassion and witnessing ourselves in the lives and stories of others is a powerful motivator

We all eventually think about the impact we want to have on the world, the legacies we want to leave behind. 

Which always brings me back to the question. What kind of ancestors do we want to be?

And so, with these insights and this current moment in human history, I’m taking advantage of this liminal space, to create, to co-create. I want to use this small window of time between where we are and where we want to be to be proactive rather than reactive in my role and responsibility to creating the future that I want to live in.

I have an urgent plan of action and this is where you come in. 


 

Backstory:

 

I’m a polymath. 

“... an individual whose knowledge spans a significant number of subjects, known to draw on complex bodies of knowledge to solve specific problems.” (Wikipedia).

I’ve always been able to recognise and decode patterns, especially those in worlds that normally don’t fit together. 

I’m a futurist. I take a philosophical and anthropological approach to technology and am interested in the anatomy transformation. 

I’m a science enthusiast. I’m interested in quantum mechanics and how it appears in our lives, patterns of behaviour and rituals.

I’m spiritual and have explored the worlds of the shaman, natural, ancestral and indigenous knowledge. 

I’m also an artist. One who is not constrained by a particular medium. 

After years keeping these sides of myself separate I have found a way to combine them and for the first time in my life I feel whole. 

Cyborg shamanism is the result of six years of recognising patterns. Patterns seen in the knowledge, wisdom, rituals, behaviours and technologies from those different cultures and communities that I had immersed myself. This led me to see a way to use these patterns to create a new framework for transformation and storytelling. An alternative to the traditional Hero’s Journey that instead of focussing on a solo adventurer writes us all in on that journey, all with a starring role to play.

This crowdfunding page is about the first step in helping turn that into a reality.

For the last year I was invited to speak at conferences around the world, the reception to cyborg shamanism has been outstanding. But, now is the time of the storytellers, the artists, the creatives.

We all are, and can be artists. 

 

The opportunity:

And then, a few weeks ago I was given a life changing opportunity. 

A series of serendipitous incidences has led to me being offered an unconditional place to study for an MA in Immersive Storytelling at The Royal Holloway University which is part of The StoryFutures Academy. The kicker is that the programme starts on the 21st of September 2020!

This newly created programme would enable me combine these elements of who I am to explore and design immersive storytelling experiences that could be a catalyst for the changes that we want to make in unprecedented time between where we are and where we want to be. 

But, I need your urgent help to make it happen. 


 

Scene - Cyborg Shamanism:

 

What is cyborg shamanism? 

In its simplest form it’s a new ism, a framework that can be a way for us to live our lives whilst actively creating spaces and experiences in the on and offline world where the voices, stories, wisdom and knowledge of those who have been Othered are sought, heard and held. 

The word ‘cyborg’ is used to challenge us to think about what it means to be human. The ethics, power, responsibility, boundaries and possibilities of what is possible AND what we are capable of.

The word ‘shamanism’ is used as a call to actively seek and find other perspectives, other ways of knowing to give us a truly inclusive and holistic approach to solving problems and telling stories.

I created a framework that brought the worlds of algorithmic technology, quantum mechanics, spirituality and shamanism together to recognise some of the similarities the ritualistic behaviours in those worlds. I’ve been using the framework to help people, organisations and cultures deconstruct some isms, ideologies which have been used to govern or tell particular stories. 

As an artist and trans-disciplinary storyteller I also used it to curate and run an immersive performance art experience at the Tate Modern last November.

I would like to be able to take this opportunity to further develop and scale the potential of this framework but I can’t do it alone. An artist does not exist in isolation, we have a symbiotic relationship with our patrons, our viewers, our audiences. I cannot create a work of art without you being an integral part of the process. Therefore, I am proposing that rather than creating a transactional relationship between artist and potential donor I’m offering a creative one. Rather than contributors you will all become actors, co-creators and participants in a year long immersive storytelling experience.

 

The programme:

The MA in Immersive Storytelling at The Royal Holloway University as part of The StoryFutures Academy. The programme is being taught by Mary Matheson, Director of five-part 360 GoogleVR series The Female Planet. Mary is currently directing a ten-part 360 series on teenage female activists around the world. She is Executive Producer and Series Director for A Brighter Future, an interactive VR series showcasing positive solutions to the SDG (UN Sustainable Development Goals). Last year Mary wrote, produced and directed Nobody's Listening, an interactive VR experience and exhibition to commemorate the genocide by ISIS genocide against Yazidis. It would be an honour to learn from Mary. 

 

 

The ask:

The programme starts on the 21st of September 2020 as a 1-year full-time programme of study based just outside of London. 

I am aiming to raise £11,200 to cover the course fees plus an estimated £20K to cover additional admin and research costs, and contribute to initial R&D and production costs. 

It has already been a whirlwind of an experience.

I was invited to apply at the end of May 2020.

I submitted my application and was offered an unconditional place at the end of June 2020.

Unfortunately, I am too late for most of the usually available grants and the economic impact of COVID-19 pandemic has had a detrimental effect on the Arts and Culture sector which makes me even more determined for us to make a collective contribution to ensuring that we have a sector to participate and learn from when we finally come out of this pandemic. 

 

What you get:

I will be offering a tiered financial contribution system linked to the role of someone involved in the performance, commissioning, production, distribution and viewing of an immersive story. I will foster a relationship between myself and you based on the role that you choose to adopt; the scene extra, the actor. You can also hire me through the platform as a storyteller, a facilitator, curator and co-producer, futurist and an artist. Each role will be fulfilled by me using the lens of cyborg shamanism and insights taken directly from my experiences on the year long immersive storytelling programme. 

 

Risks and challenges:

What will the end product look and feel like? I don’t know, but that is also part of the beauty of this immersive experience, we will learn and grow together. I’ll share my experiences of immersing myself into this world of emerging technologies in order to recognise more patterns and connect more dots. 

 

 

“Nature loves courage. 

You make the commitment and nature will respond to that commitment by removing impossible obstacles. Dream the impossible dream and the world will not grind you under, it will lift you up. This is the trick. This is what all these teachers and philosophers who really counted, who really touched the alchemical gold, this is what they understood. This is the shamanic dance in the waterfall. 

This is how magic is done. By hurling yourself into the abyss and discovering it's a feather bed.” 

Terence McKenna

 

Other ways you can help:

Please spread the word. 

Instagram, Facebook, Twitter or LinkedIn word of mouth can go a long way.

Use the hashtags #cyborgshamanism and #isms

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt: Cyborg Shamanism: An alternative to the traditional Hero’s Journey.Instead of focusing on a solo adventurer we all travel together. Join me and become a part of our immersive storytelling future. ​“You never change things by fighting the existing reality.To change something, build a new model that makes the existing model obsolete.”― Buckminster Fuller The old ‘normal’ is well and truly broken.The COVID-19 pandemic has subverted the status quo, we can’t go back to what was. Do we really want to anyhow?What we once knew to be ‘normal’ no longer exists. As devastating as the impact of COVID-19 has been we have also been presented with an opportunity. An opportunity to leave old beliefs, rituals, behaviours and narratives behind. To remember to breathe and to grow alone and together. To remind ourselves of what being in flow feels like and to ground ourselves in these new rituals and stories of who we really are when we remove many of the distractions.I was one of the many thousands in the UK who had to shield, the harshest form of lockdown because I am immunocompromised. I started the year with speaker gigs booked through until August 2020, after 10 years on the Keynote speaking circuit this was a first. I had finally broken through. All of the sacrifices had been worth it. And then, the coronavirus struck. Within 2 weeks I had lost all of my work and potential earnings for the year and possible longer because I had to shield. Instead of seeing the lockdown as a quarantine I chose to see it as a period of metamorphosis, of transformation. A time to create some new isms.Whilst in my cocoon I noticed three things about what was happening in the world outside:If we break down human made boundaries and come together then we are capable of much more than we could have imaginedEmpathy, compassion and witnessing ourselves in the lives and stories of others is a powerful motivatorWe all eventually think about the impact we want to have on the world, the legacies we want to leave behind. Which always brings me back to the question. What kind of ancestors do we want to be?And so, with these insights and this current moment in human history, I’m taking advantage of this liminal space, to create, to co-create. story:
Scope

Black Space Matters will be held at Art and Sol Studios on Friday, December 2, 2016 (7PM-12AM) featuring visual works by Andre Jones and Sephora Woldu.

In addition to a shared vision with Art and Sol Studios owner Christina Madison, Alena Museum's founder Hager Asefaha believes Black Space Matters is informed by the reality that maintaining space in an increasingly gentrifying world is crucial, and that with the displacement of communities comes the threat of lost opportunity to cultivate and explore identities. 

 

The Work

Mural: "United States of Melanin"

Inspired by the diversity of artists both Art and Sol Studios and Alena Museum work with (and the fact that every human heritage possesses melanin in their makeup), United States of Melanin is a wall of faces from around the world featured side by side, playfully interacting with each other. Designed by Andre Jones, the intent of the mural is to illustrate the cultural ecosystem of identities that inspire our work. A brief sketch of some of the faces featured in the mural:

 

United States of Melanin will be displayed on the front wall of Art and Sol Studios (rough grid of the wall space to be utilized below).

 Wall A will have 12 faces lined above the Art and Sol Studios name, with a distinct margin of black separating artwork from the text. Wall B and D will have 6 faces (3x2 grid), and Wall C will have 4 (2x2). The mural will have an interactive element in the last face of Wall D, which will instead be a mirror— meaning that anyone who walks by will see themselves in the mural. #deep

Video Installation: "Black Space Matters"

Black Space Matters is an ode to black owned space and the possibilities that can be created with their support. Directed by Sephora Woldu, the video installation will include time lapse imaging of the mural as well as experimental elements, both historical and abstract.

 

The Team

  • Hager Asefaha, Founder, Alena Museum 
  • Sephora Woldu, Filmmaker/ Visual Artist
  • Andre 'Natty Rebel' Jones, Muralist

 

What we are raising funds for

We launched this Indiegogo campaign to help the Alena team to make it to Miami. All proceeds will be used to cover travel, accommodations and art supplies for the team as well as a full-time photographer and videographer to document the trip.

story:
Short Introduction

Hi there!

My name is Artyom Yefimov, aka artefy. I’m a freelance digital artist and illustrator. You can see some of my projects in my portfolio at www.behance.net/artefy or visit my personal page at artefy.name.

I always do a perfect job. Of course, to make some really cool things may take a long time. I like to work for clients and be compensated accordingly. But not all of my works are commissioned. Sometimes, I create images just for fun, as a self-expression.

The Project

About seven years ago, I made a photorealistic vector illustration of jumping rainbow trout. It has become the beginning of art series. Since that time, the collection was expanded by few more digital artworks made in the same style. Some friends of mine said that it might be a good art project named perhaps “Fisherman’s Eye Catchers”. Indeed, why not? Images might be published as stickers and posters. Another option is a wall calendar. Game fishers or marine life lovers may appreciate it. This set could attract private collectors, or liven up the interior of a fisherman’s club or a seafood restaurant.

Here is an example of how the posters look like:

I’m going to create ten more images to make a set of 15 game fishes. Here is the list of species to be included in the set:

  • Largemouth Bass (done)
  • Blue Marlin (done)
  • Sailfish (done)
  • Rainbow Trout (done)
  • Atlantic Cod (done)
  • Yellowfin Tuna
  • Tarpon
  • Mako Shark
  • Mahi Mahi
  • Bluefin Trevally
  • Red Drum
  • Opah
  • Coho Salmon
  • Wahoo
  • Grayling

The Workflow

The process of creating a digital artwork is divided in several stages from the very first sketch to the final detail. It takes 3 to 4 weeks per image. Here is an example of the workflow process:

The Campaign

To launch this project, I decided to start a crowdfunding campaign. I need to find enough funds to be able to concentrate on this project full-time. To complete it will require several months, maybe a year. By supporting my campaign, you will show you recognize the value of this project and help me bring my art to other interested people. Basically, you become my patrons.

What I Need & What You Get

I need funds to complete the project. And you should and will be compensated. As soon as the project is complete, all artworks can be printed in a set, such as a wall calendar. There is always a risk. But, certain artwork is already done and I can have it printed for you through a print service. I certainly hope the campaign will be successful and I’ll get a chance to complete a whole set of pictures.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not ready to donate, yet willing to help? Then share the information with your friends. Every positive word might be helpful.

story:
WHY FUND #toilettour ?

In a world where human beings expose themselves constantly through the lens of social media, where do we allow ourselves to be vulnerable? The answer is TOILETS.  Toilets are our last private space. In this body of work, artist and @toilettourinternational creator, Kelly Moore, seeks what it is to be vulnerable.  How will it affect human nature when our private space becomes public domain? ART and ART ALONE can answer these questions. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise initially $2000 which will cover airfare and accommodations for the Norway leg of Toilet Tour.  We are starting in Norway because, apparently, it's the happiest country on Earth.  Is it because of their toilets? We will find out!

  • If you donate at least $5 you will get a personalized Instagram shoutout!
  • If you donate at least $10 you will get an Instagram shoutout AND a choice of 1 of the 3 Cardboard Kellys
  • If you donate at least $20 you will get an Instagram shoutout AND a choice of 2 of the 3 Cardboard Kellys
  • If you donate at least $40 you will get an Instagram shoutout AND all 3 Cardboard Kellys
  • What is a Cardboard Kelly?  It is a cardboard cutout of artist and @toilettourinternational creator, Kelly Moore.  Use this Kelly to create your own #toilettour creation on social media!

The Impact

The art world will be forever changed by this body of work.

Risks & Challenges

  • Many people will not take this seriously, however, Kelly has a Masters of Fine Art and is qualified to take toilet selfies.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this campaign!
  • Follow @toilettourinternational on instagram!
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

  • We are a group of 3rd year Film and Television students at Falmouth University who aim to create a documentary that shines a light on rehabilitation in UK prisons.
  • For our final year project we aim to make an insightful documentary that focuses on the UK prison system and the remarkable art and writing created within.
  • By supporting our campaign you will be part of a inspiring and eye opening piece of filmmaking which we hope will project us into the industry after our graduation. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to cover our transport costs. Driving to anywhere from Cornwall is far and expensive.  We've already filmed in London which cost £120 and plan to make more trips to prison art exhibitions in Birmingham which will cost roughly the same.
  • Music license fees are also expensive! We aim to use the song Human by Rag'n'Bone Man.  
  • Other costs are for catering, accommodation, merchandise and archive footage. 
  • We have perks so you get something back for supporting us! We have a range of merchandise like tote bags, posters, stickers, DVDs and credits on our film!

The Impact

  • This project shows an artistic perspective on people in prison and ex-convicts.
  •  In other parts of the world, people who are sent to prison are worked with intensely to help them to reform so they are able to re-enter society as a productive member.
  • In the UK, our prisons are overcrowded and understaffed. They also lack the funding to make them safe places for rehabilitation. The ideal situation would be a programme, such as ones run by the  Koestler Trust, that give prisoners time and space to work at a craft such as art or writing. They need the structure and opportunity to grow as a person.
  • We've been inspired by the Koestler Trust and the Prison Reform Trust as they work in different ways to promote the writing and arts of prisoners. They have given us insight into their aims and explained how they work to help those in prison. 

Risks & Challenges.

  • Our main challenge is to gain access to people in prison who have been helped by art and writing. To gain access would be amazing for our proposed film. However, after the recent unrest, reported in the media, it will be almost impossible to gain access to make a student film.
  • We will be contacting lower category prisons that specialise in rehabilitation with a low record of misconduct. The safer and lower risk the prison the more likely we are to gain access. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please get in touch with your own stories about people you may know who have been to prison and have found their own way of coping or passing the time.
  • If you are unable to give some funds you can also help by liking and sharing our posts on social media.

LFBB Facebook page:  https://www.facebook.com/LettersFromBehindBars/

LFBB Instagram:            https://www.instagram.com/letters_from_behind_b...

What We Need & What You Get

We need to cover our transport costs. Driving to anywhere from Cornwall is far and expensive.  We've already filmed in London which cost £120 and plan to make more trips to prison art exhibitions in Birmingham which will cost roughly the same.
Music license fees are also expensive! We aim to use the song Human by Rag'n'Bone Man.  
Other costs are for catering, accommodation, merchandise and archive footage. 
We have perks so you get something back for supporting us! We have a range of merchandise like tote bags, posters, stickers, DVDs and credits on our film!



The Impact

This project shows an artistic perspective on people in prison and ex-convicts.
 In other parts of the world, people who are sent to prison are worked with intensely to help them to reform so they are able to re-enter society as a productive member.
In the UK, our prisons are overcrowded and understaffed. They also lack the funding to make them safe places for rehabilitation. The ideal situation would be a programme, such as ones run by the  Koestler Trust, that give prisoners time and space to work at a craft such as art or writing. They need the structure and opportunity to grow as a person.
We've been inspired by the Koestler Trust and the Prison Reform Trust as they work in different ways to promote the writing and arts of prisoners. They have given us insight into their aims and explained how they work to help those in prison. 


Risks & Challenges.

Our main challenge is to gain access to people in prison who have been helped by art and writing. To gain access would be amazing for our proposed film. However, after the recent unrest, reported in the media, it will be almost impossible to gain access to make a student film.
We will be contacting lower category prisons that specialise in rehabilitation with a low record of misconduct. The safer and lower risk the prison the more likely we are to gain access. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please get in touch with your own stories about people you may know who have been to prison and have found their own way of coping or passing the time.
If you are unable to give some funds you can also help by liking and sharing our posts on social media.

LFBB Facebook page:  https://www.facebook.com/LettersFromBehindBars/
LFBB Instagram:            https://www.instagram.com/letters_from_behind_b...

story:
Hello friends..!!!

I am Jaijea Kuruvilla from Aleppey India, currently practicing music and theatre with an art collective called Oorali.

I grew up in Aleppey and was working in Tourism industry, successfully running a b&b. Few months before i met the theater based music group called oorali.it draw my attention.There is a bus with performers  and this bus can be opened to a performing space and brings out great folk music and theatre.I left my business slowly and i moved with them as part of it

THE REASON/PROJECT

    The magic bus is currently going through rennovation .the whole idea is to get the bus back in action and travel to remote villages do perfomances,play music coordinate workshops.We need your support to finish the work of the bus which is halfly done and to gather funds for the journey of 40-60 days throughout kerala.

 

WHY SUPPORT MAGIC BUS

The bus would need a figure of 2000 $ to finish the job.the work is in progress even wen i write.

The jobs to be done

  • purchase materials for the body
  • painting jobs 
  • design 
  • performing space reconditioning
  • interior

For the perfomances and workshops -1000$

  • to collect materials for workshops and perfomances

  • to coordinate the journey

Where the funds go

An unique art bus that moves from one places to another.reach out to villages cities .communicate them through theatre music conversations

For the donations you make we will be able to deliver perfomances ,hand out craft boxes.hand made instruments and organise workshops on music ,painting,acting,crafts

THE CHANGE YOU MAKE

In kerala Southern india  we are rich in art and tradition but art have been minimised to televisions and mobilephones .A wonder of a buscarnival will be an inspiration for people to take an another step.To spread a band culture and moving theatre this would be the right way.There are not many art groups who take inspiring steps to spread art.to share experiences.we are looking more to reach to children as the journey will be in summer vacation.in the past experiences with the bus it have been positive .hope we can together recreate the magic bus

SHARE AND SUPPORT

All single shares can help us to  to do what we love .......please do share our magic bus with people you know.like all single coin counts every share counts....

story:
Le projet vénitien du pavillon du Liban – Présentation du projet artistique

 

Le projet conçu par Zad Moultaka pour le pavillon du Liban unit architecture visuelle et composition sonore. Il associe les recherches musicales et plastiques de l’artiste dans une synergie de formes, de matières et de sons.

 

Le propos de l’artiste Zad Moultaka : «Tout reposait sur Ur et Jeita »

Au sein de notre civilisation qui se perd sur les rives du matérialisme et se noie à la surface du visible, il est impératif et urgent de questionner le sacré dans le cœur même de l’homme. Il y a 36 000 ans, l’homme descendait dans le ventre de la terre, afin d’y graver des signes et des formes animales empruntés au monde mystérieux qu’il côtoyait avec crainte et humilité. Il rentrait dans les entrailles de la montagne en questionnant les parois de pierre avec de l’argile et du bois brûlé, comme s’il ressentait une présence derrière ces surfaces rigides, ondulantes et escarpées. L’Homo Sapiens de notre Préhistoire était relié à un autre espace, au-delà du monde visible. Il posait ses mains chargées de terre sur la peau de la roche, pour en apprivoiser et en caresser les forces obscures afin, peut-être, d’établir de nouvelles lois pour vivre ensemble.

Le projet du pavillon libanais pour la Biennale de Venise se veut au centre de ce questionnement à travers un dialogue spatial, temporel et sonore entre Ur, Jeita et Alep, lieux de prière immémoriaux, de terribles violences actuelles et tout de puissance symbolique du Proche Orient. Il prendra place dans l’ancien chantier naval civil et militaire de la flotte vénitienne.
šamaš s’enracine mentalement, physiquement et philosophiquement dans le refus du drame auquel nous assistons dans cette région solaire du monde qu’est le Moyen Orient, berceau des civilisations orientale et occidentale. L’apocalypse arabe, qui menace de mettre fin à ces civilisations, n’est pas inévitable. En souvenir de mes premières descentes dans le cœur de la grotte de Jeita, j’ai voulu retourner dans le ventre de la terre, afin d’en extirper la sagesse perdue. Car je sais que l’énergie restée intacte dans les profondeurs de ces pierres est prête à ressurgir, avec une mystérieuse puissance de cadences et de cascades. Sous les dieux du ciel bombardé de Syrie, on peut encore entrevoir l’émergence des premiers codes de lois babyloniens tout comme l’érection des temples géants de Baalbek. L’homme d’aujourd’hui a été arraché au sol, il s’est décroché du ciel. Sourd et aveugle à l’essence des choses, il programme son propre effacement, précipitant avec lui, par angoisse, l’effritement du monde…

story:
At the center of the installation are life-sized sculptures of the bombs that dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945. The bombs are made from the kimonos of Yuki’s grandmother, sewn together with the artist’s own hair, melding the DNA of generations of atomic bomb survivors. Yuki’s writings and drawings, in English and Japanese, surround the bombs, creating a place of dark reverence. A soundscape floats on the air. Visitors slow down, step more softly, quietly engage and reflect.

Though Suspended Moment began as a solo project, it has been augmented over the past two years through focused collaborations. Each installation of Suspended Moment includes a Butoh performance by dancer/choreographer Meshi Chavez, with music by Lisa DeGrace. Butoh emerged as a dance form in post-World War II Japan. Poetry by Los Alamos born poet Allison Cobb enriches the performance further.

Yuki’s vision is simple and profound: bring Suspended Moment to the most important nuclear sites around the world:  Hanford Washington, where the materials for the bomb dropped on Nagasaki were created. Los Alamos, where the bombs were built. Hiroshima. Nagasaki. Fukushima. Adelaide, South Australia, a site for hundreds of nuclear tests. At each site, in addition to the installation, the artists will engage with local communities through a Butoh workshop and performance, bringing an even more personal aspect to those participants. Initial funding of $8,500 will bring us to Hanford and Los Alamos.

By allowing viewers to personally connect with our dark nuclear past, we hope to prevent these events from repeating in the future.

SUSPENDED MOMENT IS BEING SPONSORED BY THE NEW YORK FOUNDATION OF ARTS

 

 

An excerpt from Hatch the Future Podcast: Reflecting on a Nuclear Legacy.

 

An interview with Joe Mclaughlin, a participant in the first Suspended Moment performance in 2014

 

What We Need & What You Get

Here are the funding tiers for Suspended Moment  --how far the funding will take us!

  • The $8,500, will cover lodging, travel expenses, artist fee for four, art materials, renting venues and the cost for recording the event.

-----------------------and our future plans are------------------------

  • Raising $22,000, we can take the project to Hiroshima, Japan!
  • Raising $27,000, we can take the project to Hiroshima and Fukushima!
  • Raising $30,000, we can take the project to Hiroshima, Fukushima and Tokyo!
  • Raising $33,000, we can take the project to Hiroshima, Fukushima, Tokyo and Nagasaki!
  • Raising $44,000, we can take the project to Adelaide, South Australia!

 

Please check out our special thank-you gift!

For all donations, you will get a special "shout out" on FaceBook!

For your contribution $99~ (plus shipping), we will send Yukiyo Kawano's original Linocut print, representation of Katsushika Hokusai's 36 views of Mt. Fuji (1826 - 1833). Instead of famous Mt. Fuji, a popular subject in Japanese art due to its cultural and religious significance, Kawano's prints depict a pair of cooling towers.

This ongoing series are called 36 views of Nuke.

story:
Cotonfioc Festival è il nuovo prodotto del collettivo Gossypium (vi ricordate Gelati Fanzine Festival?) con l’ambizioso obiettivo di tuffarsi nel mondo delle auto-produzioni in maniera innovativa: innanzitutto attraverso la location scelta, non più in centro storico ma a Marassi, area della città famosa soprattutto per lo stadio; in secondo luogo ampliando i propri confini verso nuove forme d’arte.

La manifestazione, realizzata con il patrocinio del Municipio Bassa Valbisagno del Comune di Genova, si prefigge ormai di portata internazionale.

Cotonfioc #1 è una due giorni di mostre, concerti, market e workshop che verranno concentrati in un unico spazio espositivo, lo spettacolare Ex Mercato ortofrutticolo della città, ormai in disuso e in cerca di una nuova identità.

Ecco il link per seguire gli aggiornamenti sulla line up ufficiale del festival: EVENTO FB

Nelle prossime settimane vi presenteremo tutti i nostri ospiti, intanto ecco cosa segnare in agenda:

_Sabato 6 maggio
Ore 14: apertura market delle autoproduzioni.

Ecco le istruzioni per partecipare come espositore: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B8pyyt__mwHkU...

Ore 15-18: stampa letterpress live a cura di Officina Nove Punti
Ore 18: inizio concerti
Ore 23: chiusura

_Domenica 7 maggio
Ore 14: apertura market delle autoproduzioni
Ore 15: performance live di Officina Nove Punti
Ore 18: inizio concerti
Ore 23: chiusura

LINE UP IN AGGIORNAMENTO

Rimarranno allestite per l'intera durata della rassegna le seguenti mostre:

/ INONDAZIONE
Alla mostra ufficiale di COTONFIOC Festival hanno partecipato illustratori e fotografi che hanno affrontato e personalizzato il delicato e fantastico tema dell'inondazione. 

Ecco le istruzioni per partecipare: https://www.facebook.com/events/1807473322806697/

||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||

/ GRAPHISTE
Curata da Rossana Calbi e Alessia Defilippi, questa collettiva di undici illustratrici italiane con stili, percorsi ed età differenti, ha la volontà di raccontare come si sta muovendo l’illustrazione al femminile in Italia.

In mostra le tavole di:
Margherita Barrera
Alessandra De Cristofaro
Marina Girardi
Little Points
Luisa Montalto Art
VirginiaMori
Daria Palotti
il Pistrice
Irene Rinaldi
Daniela Tieni
Olimpia Zagnoli

||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||

/ LÖK ZINE #08 PIANTE
Lök Zine vi invita a un tuffo nella natura che indaga il tema della crescita e il mondo vegetale in tutte le sue incredibili sfaccettature, ma anche piante in senso di mappe e percorsi, composizioni di strutture e ambienti che prendono vita nell'ultimo numero del magazine che raccoglie la migliore selezione di illustrazione e fumetto contemporaneo.

In mostra le tavole di:
Marco Goran Romano 
Lucia Manfredi 
Lia Tuia 
Andrea De Luca
Fatomale 
Giuliano Buttafuoco 
Davor Gromilović 
Salvatore Giommarresi
Carol Rollo 
Martoz 
La Lois
Chester Holme
Martina Gentile
Martina Grasso
Alessandro Cripsta
Anna Wieszczyk
Fausto Montanari

||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||

I protagonisti e visitatori di COTONFIOC potranno rifocillarsi al punto ristoro del festival, a cui presenzieranno Andrea e Chiara de Il Sapore del Fiore di Ciliegio con le loro specialità della tradizione giapponese.

L'ingresso al festival è, come sempre, gratuito.

Cotonfioc Festival è organizzato dall’Associazione Culturale no-profit Gossypium, nata a Genova nel 2015 e composta da menti e mani grafiche, illustratrici, musicali.

Nove personalità e professionalità eterogenee accomunate da due passioni: quella per l'arte e quella per Genova.

Attraverso l'organizzazione di eventi e manifestazioni a ingresso gratuito, l'obiettivo di Gossypium è quello di offrire una cultura fruibile a tutti, affinché essa possa diffondersi e svilupparsi.

-

Does Gelati Fanzine Festival sound familiar?
Cotonfioc Festival is the new Gossypium project. Its ambitious goal is to dive into the self-productions world in a whole innovative way, starting with the chosen location. No longer the old town but the decentered area of Marassi. Secondly, the festival aims to expand its borders to new forms of art.

The event, organized under the patronage of the Municipio Bassa Valbisagno of the Municipality of Genoa, seeks now an international dimension.

Cotonfioc #1 is a two days of market, exhibitions, concerts and workshops that will all take place in a single exhibition space, the spectacular former fruit and vegetable market of the city, now disused and looking for a new identity.

EVENT ON FB

In the coming weeks we will present all our guests; in the meantime here what to put in your to do list:

_Saturday, May 6th
2pm: opening of self-productions market.

Here are the instructions to participate as exhibitor:https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B8pyyt__mwHkU...

3pm-6pm: letterpress printing - live by Officina Nove Punti
6pm: live concerts
11pm: closing time

_Sunday, May 7th
2pm: opening of self-productions market.
3pm: performance live by Officina Nove Punti
6pm: live concerts
11pm: closing time

UPDATES TO FOLLOW

The following exhibitions will be set up for the entire duration of the fair:

/ FLOOD
The official exhibition of COTONFIOC Festival has been attended by illustrators and photographers who have dealt with the delicate and personal and fantastic theme of flood..

Here all the instructions to participate: https://www.facebook.com/events/1807473322806697/

||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||

/ GRAPHISTE
Curated by Rossana Calbi and Alessia Defilippi, this collective of eleven Italian illustrators with styles, paths and different ages, has the will to tell how female illustration is developing in Italy.

Artworks by:
Margherita Barrera
Alessandra De Cristofaro
Marina Girardi
Little Points
Luisa Montalto Art
VirginiaMori
Daria Palotti
il Pistrice
Irene Rinaldi
Daniela Tieni
Olimpia Zagnoli

||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||

/ LÖK ZINE #08 PLANTS
Lök Zine invites you to dive into nature that explores the theme of growth and the whole plant world in all its amazing aspects; but also plants in the sense of maps and routes, compositions of structures and environments that come alive in the last issue of the magazine that collects the best selection of contemporary illustration and comics.

Artworks by:
Marco Goran Romano
Lucia Manfredi
Lia Tuia
Andrea De Luca
Fatomale
Giuliano Buttafuoco
Davor Gromilović
Salvatore Giommarresi
Carol Rollo
Martoz
La Lois
Chester Holme
Martina Gentile
Martina Grasso
Alessandro Cripsta
Anna Wieszczyk
Fausto Montanari

||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||

All COTONFIOC guests can refresh themselves at the food court of the festival, who will attend Andrea and Chiara of Il Sapore del Fiore di Ciliegio with their specialties of Japanese tradition.

As always, free entry.

Cotonfioc Festival is organized by the Cultural nonprofit Gossypium, born in Genoa in 2015 thanks to nine eclectic personalities united by two passions: for art and for Genoa.

Through the organization of free-events, Gossypium aims to make culture more and more accessible, so that it can spread and develop.

percorsi, composizioni di strutture e ambienti che prendono vita nell'ultimo numero del magazine che raccoglie la migliore selezione di illustrazione e fumetto contemporaneo.In mostra le tavole di:Marco Goran Romano Lucia Manfredi Lia Tuia Andrea De LucaFatomale Giuliano Buttafuoco Davor Gromilović Salvatore GiommarresiCarol Rollo Martoz La LoisChester HolmeMartina GentileMartina GrassoAlessandro CripstaAnna WieszczykFausto Montanari||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||I protagonisti e visitatori di COTONFIOC potranno rifocillarsi al punto ristoro del festival, a cui presenzieranno Andrea e Chiara de Il Sapore del Fiore di Ciliegio con le loro specialità della tradizione giapponese.L'ingresso al festival è, come sempre, gratuito.Cotonfioc Festival è organizzato dall’Associazione Culturale no-profit Gossypium, nata a Genova nel 2015 e composta da menti e mani grafiche, illustratrici, musicali.Nove personalità e professionalità eterogenee accomunate da due passioni: quella per l'arte e quella per Genova.Attraverso l'organizzazione di eventi e manifestazioni a ingresso gratuito, l'obiettivo di Gossypium è quello di offrire una cultura fruibile a tutti, affinché essa possa diffondersi e svilupparsi.-Does Gelati Fanzine Festival sound familiar?Cotonfioc Festival is the new Gossypium project. Its ambitious goal is to dive into the self-productions world in a whole innovative way, starting with the chosen location. No longer the old town but the decentered area of Marassi. Secondly, the festival aims to expand its borders to new forms of art.The event, organized under the patronage of the Municipio Bassa Valbisagno of the Municipality of Genoa, seeks now an international dimension.Cotonfioc #1 is a two days of market, exhibitions, concerts and workshops that will all take place in a single exhibition space, the spectacular former fruit and vegetable market of the city, now disused and looking for a new identity.EVENT ON FBIn the coming weeks we will present all our guests; in the meantime here what to put in your to do list:_Saturday, May 6th2pm: opening of self-productions market.Here are the instructions to participate as exhibitor:https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B8pyyt__mwHkU...3pm-6pm: letterpress printing - live by Officina Nove Punti6pm: live concerts11pm: closing time_Sunday, May 7th2pm: opening of self-productions market.3pm: performance live by Officina Nove Punti6pm: live concerts11pm: closing timeUPDATES TO FOLLOWThe following exhibitions will be set up for the entire duration of the fair:/ FLOODThe official exhibition of COTONFIOC Festival has been attended by illustrators and photographers who have dealt with the delicate and personal and fantastic theme of flood..Here all the instructions to participate: https://www.facebook.com/events/1807473322806697/||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||/ GRAPHISTECurated by Rossana Calbi and Alessia Defilippi, this collective of eleven Italian illustrators with styles, paths and different ages, has the will to tell how female illustration is developing in Italy.Artworks by:Margherita BarreraAlessandra De CristofaroMarina GirardiLittle PointsLuisa Montalto ArtVirginiaMoriDaria Palottiil PistriceIrene RinaldiDaniela TieniOlimpia Zagnoli||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||/ LÖK ZINE #08 PLANTSLök Zine invites you to dive into nature that explores the theme of growth and the whole plant world in all its amazing aspects; but also plants in the sense of maps and routes, compositions of structures and environments that come alive in the last issue of the magazine that collects the best selection of contemporary illustration and comics.Artworks by:Marco Goran RomanoLucia ManfrediLia TuiaAndrea De LucaFatomaleGiuliano ButtafuocoDavor GromilovićSalvatore GiommarresiCarol RolloMartozLa LoisChester HolmeMartina GentileMartina GrassoAlessandro CripstaAnna WieszczykFausto Montanari||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||All COTONFIOC guests can refresh themselves at the food court of the festival, who will attend Andrea and Chiara of Il Sapore del Fiore di Ciliegio with their specialties of Japanese tradition.As always, free entry.Cotonfioc Festival is organized by the Cultural nonprofit Gossypium, born in Genoa in 2015 thanks to nine eclectic personalities united by two passions: for art and for Genoa.Through the organization of free-events, Gossypium aims to make culture more and more accessible, so that it can spread and develop.

story:
Short Summary

Students from Coventry University are looking to find funds from the generous public by asking for your kind help and support.

The funding received would help us cover the cost of hiring a venue within London (the most accessible city of England). Sufficient funding will also help pay for the online magazine that will cover a vast range of artists’ work as well as uncovering articles glorifying certain types of art forms as opposed to other types.

The students have worked hard to brand their group name as ‘Verve’ to signify exactly what the word means- ‘vigour’, ‘enthusiasm’ and ‘spirit’. Each of these qualities are personal traits within the members as we are passionate about expressive art and ideas presented in the form of art. We accept that art is subjective therefore the artwork will also be subjective to each individual when producing. No matter what the ideas, the art pieces are not judged and not disparaged.

We aim to hold an exhibition to the maximum capacity of artist allowed, so that we include everyone and abandon no one. The magazine however will be published online, therefore all virtual pieces will be categorically be published, however physical such as immersive art will be prioritised to the exhibition.

Three years of studying Media Production and one year abroad in Europe has shown us the importance of loving all forms of art as expressing yourself is what makes up an individual. In a city where diversity is promoted, this campaign is the perfect way of uniting all artists who are passionate about expressing themselves in a creative artistic way.

 

What We Need & What You Get

In a nutshell, we are students, hiring out a space in London. For those that don’t understand what that means, it means that we have no secondary source of income or funds since we are in full time education we do not have the time to organise a public event as well as hold down a job. The prices in London are extortionately high but we have taken the executive decision to have it in London as it promotes a bigger better image along with promoting higher public participation. We WANT this.
That is what the whole project is all about. We want the public to get involved. Art is an expression that comes in several different shapes and forms that  can make you think as well as make you feel. We want you to immerse yourself around this art so that you are able to see how important art can be to a person and how it can really define and inspire you.

The budget will be broken down by splitting the money 75/25. The majority of the budget will be directed towards the exhibition since the physical resources we will use are greater compared to the ones online, however this is not to say that online materials will not be costing. Promotion online for example is essential to get the word of mouth around. I mean that’s why how you found this page ultimately right? Materials such as buying an annual domain name, buying high quality magazine software subscription will be needed in order to fund the magazine side of the project. The rest of the money we are trying to raise will try to cover the costs of venue hire, photo printing, décor and creating our branding online. We are hoping to host the exhibition in London, because this is the most touristic and artistic place in England; but not only that-London is known world-wide! It would be great to have such an audience able to reach our exhibition in a convenient location for us all.

 

Don’t worry if we don’t receive the full funds; we still greatly appreciate everything that we receive. Even if we do not receive the full amount we need, we know that we must fund ourselves through our own pocket. The problem however is that our pockets are limited; we cannot afford to put the whole amount into the event and magazine as we do not have any funds available to us. There are no grant schemes available either therefore every donation is accepted-small or big.

Perks- whether small or big, we will grant you a mention on our online magazine that we will publish soon after the exhibition has been conducted. The page will consist of your name and  a title as a sponsor towards our project.

Please let it be noted that these perks are not compulsory and you may wish to only donate rather than have a mention.
Please also note that contributing anonymously will mean that your name will not be mentioned but will be categorised under the ‘anonymous’ categories along with our other anonymous donors.

Even if we are not able to raise the whole £800, you can still help by spreading the word and coming down to the exhibition to come and see and get inspired by the works of everyone involved. It is all about public participation and looking at the work and the words of the artists to make you feel something.

Your support (in any form) is what will make this possible. Every donation is welcome and even if you are not able to support us monetary-wise, word of mouth about the event will help us just the same.

 

Risks & Challenges

Neither of us have done anything like this before and to do this a final project of our degree is incredibly risky but we feel as though the benefits outweigh the risks. By doing this, we are pushing ourselves out of our comfort zones and learning new skills every step of the way. These skills will be easily transferable outside of this project. We will also be proving not only our lecturers, tutors and peers, but anyone that has the fear of curating their own project as they are not ready that with the right determination and passion, we can do it because everyone needs to start somewhere. This experience is almost in a way our first form of working freelance as no guidance has been given to us, expect that of verbal advice. (Although, in all honesty, even experienced advice will be welcomed and appreciated by us!)

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are welcoming submissions for your expressive art pieces from now until 26th March 2017 with hopes of showcasing the pieces by the end of April/early May.

This page will be updated regularly but be sure to check us out on Facebook - @verveartists  where we post regular updates on our progress. Follow and like us, and don’t forget to donate and share. You know that if you were in our position or your best friend or family was in our position, you would appreciate the support so why not do the same now?

By giving a simple £2 per person means we can share the load and half the contributors so we can reach our target and stretch our budget the best we can. So come on, helping a friend in need is a friend indeed...So be our friend! We’ve only got 3 weeks to raise money. That’s 18 days! Help us please!

We look forward to hearing from you and we thank you in advance for your support!

Kind Regards,

Verve – Sheri Orekan & Eula Cardoso

story:
Le petit marché de l'art c'est une journée d'exposition ouverte à tous les artistes de la métropole rennaise, sans critères de sélection.

C'est aussi un vote du public, 10 œuvres sélectionnées pour une vente aux enchères sous le marteau de Maître Jezequel, commissaire priseur ; la possibilité de découvrir les talents qui œuvrent près de chez vous et d'acquérir à prix modéré des pièces originales, uniques, tout en aidant des artistes vivants à se développer. Pour ceux-ci, c'est surtout l'occasion de rencontrer un large public et de tisser des liens avec d'autres artistes.

Née après l’événement  "Le Petit Marché de l’Art" en avril 2017, l'association Art2rennes est une démarche collective d’artistes plasticiens pour créer ensemble des outils qui donnent une meilleure visibilité de leur travail et un accès plus facile aux ressources disponibles dans la métropole rennaise pour avancer dans leur parcours.

Art2rennes c’est aussi développer une intelligence collective entre artistes et avec le public. Nous voulons essayer d'adoucir la frontière de l'élitisme et favoriser le dialogue.

https://art.2rennes.fr

Pour la première édition, nous avions bénéficié de l'hôtel Pasteur et de sa gratuité grâce à Sophie Ricard et la mairie de Rennes. Cette année, nous avons l'opportunité d'exposer à la Halle Martenot et pouvoir ainsi accueillir plus d'artistes et de visiteurs. Grâce à Rennes Métropole, nous bénéficierons d'une aide logistique et d'une réduction sur la location mais il reste à notre charge les frais de nettoyage et de sécurité.

Afin de réduire le plus possible les frais d'inscription pour les artistes voire offrir un accès gratuit à tous, nous sollicitons votre participation financière.

Nous maintiendrons la gratuité pour les visiteurs, car il nous semble important que tous puissent découvrir les oeuvres et exprimer leurs préférences via le vote organisé pour l'occasion. 

Nous avons choisi le financement flexible car nous sommes très confiants : le "Petit Marché de l'Art" aura bel et bien lieu. Atteindre l'objectif que nous nous sommes fixés ici favorisera grandement notre démarche. Le dépasser nous permettra d'organiser de prochains évènements.

Plusieurs artistes vous proposent d'acquérir leurs oeuvres sous différents formats et supports en échange de votre contribution à notre projet. Nous les remercions pour leurs dons à l'association.

Comme l'an dernier, nous proposerons plusieurs ateliers d'initiation ou de création afin de partager avec le public notre intérêt pour les arts graphiques lors de cette édition.

Nous avons en tête quelques surprises alors suivez ce projet car il y aura du nouveau. En attendant, n'hésitez pas à poser vos questions.

Si vous ne pouvez pas contribuer financièrement, vous pouvez faire part de notre projet autour de vous et sur les réseaux sociaux (un petit click en haut à droite de cette page vous facilitera la tâche). Toute aide est la bienvenue.

Plusieurs contributions financières sont possibles selon vos envies ou moyens. Dans le cas d'oeuvres uniques, veuillez nous contacter avant de cliquer afin que nous vous réservions celle que vous aurez choisie.

Les frais de port sont inclus et les oeuvres seront envoyées en juin (2018) dans les meilleures conditions (emballage, suivi, assurance).

1 EUR:

Un grand merci pour votre contribution. Si vous le souhaitez, votre nom apparaîtra dans la section Remerciements du site de notre association ainsi que sur notre page Facebook. Toutes les contributions incluent automatiquement celle-ci.

5 EUR:

Vous recevrez une carte postale dédicacée par l'un de nos artistes donateurs : etiou, Romain D Moostik, Wcomics, Sophia Bébin Veuillez nous contacter afin de la choisir.

Wcomics:

Romain D Moostik:

etiou:

Sophia Bébin :

25 EUR:

Vous recevrez un dessin d'etiou (aquarelle et encre sur papier, 10 par 15 cm) parmi les six modèles ci-dessous. Veuillez nous contacter afin de le choisir.

60 EUR:

Une peinture acrylique unique d'Ar Furlikin sur rhodoïd d'un radis de 60 X 130 cm. Veuillez nous contacter afin de choisir l'un des trois modèles.

Chaque radis peint est unique.

60 EUR:

Vous recevrez un portrait sur carton de Thomas Demersman représentant Serge Gainsbourg de 30 X 40 cm.

80 EUR:

Vous recevrez une linogravure en édition limitée de Sophia Bébin 18 par 24 cm.

80 EUR:

Vous recevrez une impression d'une oeuvre numérique en édition limitée de Suzanne Blanchet sur aluminium dibon de 30 X 30 cm.

100 EUR:

Vous recevrez une des célèbres sculptures de radis en polystyrène d'Ar Furlukin comme celles qui décorent actuellement la ville de Rennes.

100 EUR:

Vous recevrez une peinture sur toile de Thomas Demersman représentant Claudia Cardinale de 50 X 65 cm.

100 EUR:

Vous recevrez une aquarelle réalisée dans la rue par etiou (18 par 26 cm, papier Arches) représentant Rennes et son activité. Veuillez nous contacter afin de la choisir.

120 EUR:

Vous recevrez une peinture sur toile de Thomas Demersman représentant Elvis Presley de 50 X 70 cm.

500 EUR:

Vous recevrez une toile d'un mètre sur un mètre signée par tous les artistes présents lors de l'exposition.

La précédente édition (LPMA 2017) en images:

Les 172 oeuvres présentées l'année dernière en vidéo:
